application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: An induced subgraph G of a graph H is a retract of H if there is an edgepreserving map f from H onto G such that flG is the identity map on G. A median graph is a connected graph such that for any three vertices U.V. and w, there exists a unique vertex x which lies simultaneously on some shortest (u,v)-, (v,w)-, and (w,u)-paths. It is shown that a graph G is a retract of some hypercube if and only if G is a median graph.

div.head: INTRODUCTION
div.p: The concept of retraction occurs first in general topology (cf. [5]). Motivated by the topological setting, Pavol Hell [9] investigated retractions in graphs. The definition of "retract" is as one would expect: first, given two (undirected) graphs G and H (without loops), a mapping g : V ( G ) + V ( H ) between their vertex sets is called edge-preserving if it maps adjacent vertices to adjacent vertices. Now, an edge-preserving map f: V ( H ) + V ( G ) is a retraction if there exists an edge-preserving map g : V ( G ) + V ( H ) such that f o g is the identity map of G ; then G is a retract of H. It is convenient to identify G with the subgraph of H induced by the image of G under g.

The retract construction has become a flourishing topic in graph theory (cf. [7,9-12,19-221, etc.). This is mainly because retracts and products constitute the basic ingredients of any reasonable structure theory for relational systems such as graphs or reflexive graphs (Lee, graphs with loops). This point is made precise in the papers (61 and [25].

Retractions preserve much of the structure of a given graph H. Unfortunately, it is in general hard to decide whether a certain subgraph G is obtained as a retract of H. For bipartite graphs H and special subgraphs G this is, however, readily done: if G is a tree isometrically embedded in H , then G is a retract of H (Hell [9]); or, if G is a circuit of minimal length in H, then G is a retract of H (Sabidussi,cf. [9]). The analogous results for arbitrary reflexive graphs H were obtained by Nowakowski and Rival [191. The following theorem of Duffus and Rival [7] intrigued me: The covering graph ( = undirected Hasse diagram) of a finite distributive lattice of length n is a retract of the n-dimensional hypercube en. Now, trees also are retracts of hypercubes. So, how are these two facts related? Well, trees and covering graphs of discrete distributive lattices are instances of median graphs (here "discrete" refers to the condition that all intervals be finite). A connected graph G is a median graph if every triple u,u,w admits a unique median x, that is, a vertex x which lies simultaneously on shortest paths joining u and u, u and w , w and u, respectively. Median graphs have been considered by several authors; [1-4,13-181 is a sample of papers on this subject. I will assume that the reader is somewhat familiar with the order-theoretic interpretation of median graphs (anyway, he is referred to the papers [3,4,16]). This is just a brief outline: every vertex u of a median graph G gives rise to a certain semilattice order sU on V(G) defined by x 6, y if and only if x is on a shortest path joining u and y. Notice that every order-theoretic interval with respect to su is a (finite) distributive lattice. Since any median graph is bipartite, G is the covering graph of the semilattice ( V ( G ) , S , ) . Conversely, given any so-called discrete median semilattice S, the covering graph of S is a median graph. In particular, hypercubes are the covering graphs of discrete generalized Boolean lattices (also known as lattices of all finite subsets of sets). It is important to note that median graphs are embedded in hypercubes. The interplay between median graphs and hypercubes is manifold, see papers [4,14,15,16] of Henry Martyn Mulder and his coworkers. I shall add one more aspect to the theory, viz.: "median graphs are the retracts of hypercubes."

div.head: RETRACTIONS
div.p: Every retract of a graph is an induced subgraph by definition (or, at least, can be identified with such a subgraph). Necessarily, retracts are isometric in the following sense: a subgraph G of a graph H is called isometric if every shortest path in G is also a shortest path in H. In other words, G is an isometric subgraph of H if the distance function dG of G is a restriction of the distance function dH of H. A subgraph G of H is called a convex subgraph of H if every shortest path in H joining two vertices of G belongs to G. Trivially, every convex subgraph is isometric. A connected induced subgraph G of a median graph H is called a median subgraph if for any three vertices u,u,w of G the median x of u,u,w in H belongs to G. Note that a subgraph of a median graph H is a median subgraph if and only if it is isometric in H and is a median graph in its own right. Every convex subgraph of a median graph is a median subgraph. Moreover, retracts are median subgraphs as the next lemma shows. Lemma 1. Every retract G of a median graph H is a median subgraph.

Proof. Since a retraction does not increase distances, any retraction onto G maps a shortest path in H joining two vertices of G onto a shortest path in G. Let f be a retraction of H onto G, and let u,u,w E V ( G ) . The median x of u,u,w in H lies on shortest (u,u)-, (u,w)-, and(w,u)-paths, whence so does f ( x ) . By uniqueness of medians, x and f ( x ) are equal. Therefore G is a median subgraph of H. I

In view of the preceding lemma every retract of a hypercube is a median graph. Figures 1 and3 exhibit two retracts of the cube Q 3 , namely, the 4-circuit Q2 and the 3-star. As Figures 1 and2 show, a retraction is not uniquely determined by its image. Arbitrary isometric subgraphs need not be retracts: the shaded vertices in Figure 4 induce an isometric subgraph G of Q3; G is not a retract of Q3 since the median x of u,u,w in Q3 does not belong to G.

div.head: MAXIMAL MEDIAN SUBGRAPHS
div.p: What do maximal proper median subgraphs of a given median graph look like? The answer to this question constitutes the key ingredient of the proof that median graphs are the retracts of hypercubes. First start off with an arbitrary median subgraph G of a median graph H. Assume that x is a vertex of H not in G which has exactly two neighbors a and b in G . Then there exists a unique vertex u of G adjacent to a and h.
The following five sets of vertices of G are relevant:

Now assume that x is a vertex of H not in G which is adjacent to exactly one vertex of G. Then the subgraph G[x], of H induced by V ( G ) U { x } is a median subgraph of H . On the other hand, if H properly contains G, then there must be some vertex x E V ( H ) -V ( G ) adjacent to at least one vertex of G. Three neighbors of x in G would be too many: x would be their median, which is absurd since G is a median subgraph. Therefore the number of neighbors is either 2 or I , whence either G[xI2 or G[x], is a median subgraph of H. This proves the following result.

div.head: Proposition. Let G be an induced subgraph of a median graph H. Then G is a maximal proper median subgraph of H if and only if either H = G[x], or H = G[xI2 for a suitable vertex x of H not in G .
div.p: A glance at Figure 6 The preceding fact is analogous to a result in [23] for distributive lattices. Also, the construction of G[xI2 parallels that of a minimal extension of a finite distributive lattice as performed in [24].
div.formula: Note that if H = G[x],, then H is the convex closure of G in H . Thus it is not difficult to see that if G is the covering graph of some discrete distributive lattice, then so is G[xI2.
div.p: Therefore if G is the covering graph of a maximal proper sublattice of a discrete distributive lattice L , then G is a maximal proper median subgraph of the covering graph of L .

div.head: MEDIAN GRAPHS AS RETRACTS
div.p: In view of the preceding section it is easy to see that every maximal proper median subgraph of a median graph H can be obtained as a retract of the latter. Now, for an arbitrary median subgraph G there exists a well-ordered maximal chain of median subgraphs which connects G and H . The desired retraction of H onto G is then defined recursively.
Theorem 1. Let G be an induced subgraph of a median graph H such that JV(G)J a 2 . Then G is a retract of H if and only if G is a median subgraph of H .

div.head: Proof.
div.p: If G is a retract of H , then, by Lemma 1, G is a median subgraph of H . Conversely, assume that G is a median subgraph of H . Put Go = G and let fo be the identity map of V(Go). For an ordinal a suppose that G, is a proper median subgraph of H and f, is a retraction of G, onto G . Choose a vertex x of H not in G, which is adjacent to at least one vertex of G,. Just two cases have to be considered (cf. the proof of the Proposition):

(I) x is adjacent to a unique vertex v of G,. Then G,,] = G,[x], is a median subgraph of H . Define a map h:V(G,+,) + V(G,) by letting h be the identity on V(G,) and h(x) be any vertex of G, adjacent to u.
Then fa+ I = f, 0 h is a retraction of G,, onto G extending fa.

At a limit ordinal A, let G A be the limit of all G, with a < A, that is, V(GA) = Ua<, V(GJ and E(GA) = Ua<A E(G,). Further put fA = U , , , fa. As is seen by induction fA is well-defined because for any (Y < p < A the map fa is a restriction of the map fa. Thus, fA is a retraction of G, onto G .
At some ordinal a the above iteration terminates in G, = H . Then f = f, is the required retraction of H onto G . I

It seems unlikely that one can define retractions onto given median subgraphs G nonrecursively in some straightforward manner. This is, however, possible in particular instances, e.g., trees (cf. [9,19]) or hypercubes.
Combining Theorem 1 with the embedding theorem for median graphs yields the main result.
Theorem 2. Median graphs are precisely the retracts of hypercubes.

Proof. Every median graph G can be embedded in some hypercube H a s an isometric subgraph (i.e., as a median subgraph). This fact essentially follows from results in Theorem 2 and Corollary 2 correspond to the classical result that distributive lattices are precisely the subdirect products of the two-element chain 2. Indeed, a hypercube can be regarded as a weak Cartesian power of the two-element complete graph K 2 . Thus the graph-theoretic analogue of "subdirect product" is "retract of a weak Cartesian product." Recall the definition of a weak Cartesian product G of a family (Gi)iE, of graphs (cf. for some j and xi = yi for all i f j. It is a routine matter to verify that a weak Cartesian product of median graphs is median. In fact, any weak Cartesian product of retracts of graphs Hi ( i E l) is a retract of some weak cartesian product of the Hi's. Hence from Theorem 2 one gets the next result. Corollary 3. The class of median graphs is the smallest class which contains K 2 and is closed under the formation of retracts and weak Cartesian products.

div.head: REFLEXIVE MEDIAN GRAPHS
div.p: As was indicated before there is yet another concept of retraction, viz. retracts of reflexive graphs. "Reflexive" means that the graph in question has a loop at each vertex. Now since there is no distinction between loops and other edges, a retraction of a reflexive graph may send an edge between distinct vertices to a loop at some vertex. Every retraction of a graph is, a fortiori, also a retraction of the corresponding reflexive graph. The converse does not hold-even for median graphs: given any (nonempty) convex subgraph G of a median graph H, the map f sending each vertex x of H to the unique vertex of G closest to x is a retraction of the corresponding reflexive graph. Nevertheless, every retract of a reflexive median graph is a reflexive median subgraph. To see this just look at the proof of Lemma 1. Hence the results for retracts of median graphs carry over to the reflexive case as is summarized in the concluding result.

Corollary 4. The retracts of a reflexive median graph are the reflexive median subgraphs. Reflexive median graphs are the retracts of reflexive hypercubes. The class of reflexive median graphs is the smallest class containing the reflexive K 2 and closed with respect to retracts and weak Cartesian products.

I Every finite distributive lattice L of length n can be embedded in the power set lattice 2". Consequently, the covering graph of L is a median subgraph of Qn and hence is a diameter-preserving retract of Q,,. Here a retract G of a graph H is called diameter-preserving if the diameters of G and H are the same. Now if f i s a diameter-preserving retraction of Qn onto a subgraph G, then there are vertices u,u in G with d(u,u) = n. Each vertex x of Q,, lies on some shortest path joining u = f ( u ) and u = f(u), whence so does f ( x ) . Therefore (V(G), su) is a finite distributive lattice with greatest element u. This provides another proof of the following result of[7]. The covering graphs of finite distributive lattices are precisely the diameter-preserving retracts of finite hypercubes.
